title: 113_hr1069
content: The Act is titled the "TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act" and includes a drug screening and testing program for applicants and recipients of assistance under state TANF programs. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires states to implement a drug testing program for applicants and recipients of assistance under the state TANF program. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates states to operate a program to screen and test applicants and individuals at high risk of substance abuse for illegal drug use. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires states to screen and test individuals at high risk of substance abuse for illegal drug use, with the possibility of continued testing at random intervals. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates states to screen and test high-risk individuals for illegal drug use, with potential random testing intervals. States must deny assistance to those not screened or tested for drug use. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires states to screen and test individuals for illegal drug use. States must deny assistance to those not screened or tested for drug use. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates states to screen individuals for substance abuse risk using an effective survey method. Individuals identified as high risk must undergo further evaluation for substance abuse. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires states to screen individuals for substance abuse risk using an effective survey method to determine if further evaluation is needed. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates that individuals receiving assistance must be screened for illegal drug use after the 3rd month of receiving aid, and those at high risk must undergo drug testing. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires individuals on assistance to be screened for illegal drug use after the 3rd month, with high-risk individuals undergoing drug testing. The term 'illegal drug' refers to controlled substances as defined in the Controlled Substances Act. The Secretary cannot waive these provisions under section 1115. In section 1115, the term 'illegal drug' is defined as a controlled substance under the Controlled Substances Act. If an individual is denied assistance under this section, the State must still provide assistance to other family members through protective or vendor payments to a 3rd party. The State must continue to provide assistance to other family members through protective or vendor payments to a 3rd party if an individual is denied assistance under this section. The effective date for the amendments made by this section will be the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter that begins on or after 1 year from the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter that begins on or after 1 year from the enactment of this Act. If State legislation is required for compliance, a delay is permitted. The amendments made by this Act require State legislation for compliance, allowing a delay in meeting the additional requirements without penalty until after the 1st regular session of the State legislature following the enactment of the Act. State legislation must meet additional requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter following the close of the 1st regular session of the State legislature after the Act's enactment.
